title: CVE-2022-32221: POST following PUT confusion

profile.name: curl
profile.about: cURL is an Open Source project providing a library and command-line tool for doing internet transfers

activities.message:
Thank you for your report!

We will take some time and investigate your reports and get back to you with details and possible follow-up questions as soon as we can!

My first reaction: how exactly would this be a *surprise* to the application author? This is a bug that is there, consistently and all the time. This seems like a problem that could only really hurt the application if it never once ran or were tested first, doesn't it? Because if you would just test this once, you see that it doesn't send what you expect.

I'll share with you how this manifested in my experience. My application is one that has a RESTful API and uses libcurl to implement that API with different functions for the different HTTP methods. In my testing, I do perform many methods back-to-back, but not a PUT directly followed by a POST. In my tests, there were intervening GETs (which unset the CURLOPT_UPLOAD).

Then, only rarely (as I suppose a PUT directly followed by a POST must be rare for my users), my users would experience a segfault (as the data at CURLOPT_READDATA had been freed). Unfortunately, it was extremely difficult to track down/recreate, as my users were performing POST at the time but the problem really lies in the buffer for PUT.

I do not know if my users ever inadvertently sent a PUT of data that had not been freed (when they meant to send a POST). I suppose that because this would not have generated an error, perhaps it slipped by (even though the server never received the expected POST).

From what I can tell, this bug has existed for quite some time in libcurl (for both CURLOPT_UPLOAD and the deprecated CURLOPT_PUT) and I think many folks use libcurl for RESTful APIs and other scenarios where handles are reused. However, this bug has slipped by them as well.

But yes, more robust testing should have caught this (how many times have I said that in my career?). :-)
Unfortunately, I think true test coverage for this sort of scenario requires every permutation of every possible call (for me HTTP method) followed by every other call.

I argue for a lower severity than **high** for this issue:

Use after free is a reasonably unlikely outcome, as most applications should and would use precautions for this already - especially with doing multiple operations on the same handle. In addition, it is highly unlikely that even if a use-after-free would happen, it could actually send away data successfully instead of just crashing immediately, as this seems like a problem that is very hard for any outsider to trigger and massage into happening on demand.

The risk is more obvious for a send-wrong-data, but even there there's a likelihood that the stream has already been read to the end so that calling the read callback again will just have the read pointer at the end of the content and not at the beginning.

This flaw would have to linger and remain undetected even after application testing.

I am not ruling out that the worst case scenarios *can* happen, but I deem the risk to not be overly high and in this in combination with the fact that you have to do a upload + POST combination on the same easy handle makes me say that this severity should not be set higher than **medium**.
Attached my first security advisory draft for this issue.

Re CWE-440, I'm not certain it is an expected behavior violation. CWE-440 seems to be about developer/user assumptions not matching the behavior. I see this issue as different. The documentation, etc. states that CURLOPT_POST leads to an HTTP POST, not an HTTP PUT. And that using CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS will override CURLOPT_READDATA ("If CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS is explicitly set to NULL then libcurl will get the POST data from the read callback.").

I believe the two issues cited are what could occur:
Information Disclosure (CWE-200): Data from CURLOPT_READDATA could be disclosed (via an HTTP PUT) when an HTTP POST of the information in CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS was intended. This information could be sent to a completely unintended host.
Use after free (CWE-416): Although the data from CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS was the intended data, data specified in an earlier CURLOPT_READDATA is used. This data could be long gone / freed. I would think most implementations would free this data in some way after use, as old data from an HTTP PUT is not necessarily useful and could use valuable memory.

> Use after free is a reasonably unlikely outcome, as most applications should and would use precautions for this already - especially with doing multiple operations on the same handle.

For my own benefit, could you elaborate on the precautions you have in mind? I would think in most applications, there is a buffer that needs to be PUT in dynamic (malloc) memory and once that buffer has been copied to libcurl (via CURLOPT_READFUNCTION) it would be freed and forgotten. I think most applications would not anticipate that pointer being used / called again. The only thing that comes to mind would be setting CURLOPT_READDATA to NULL - is that what you are thinking?

Thanks!

additional_data.old_title: PUT followed by POST causes incorrect data to be sent or potentially use after free

activities.message: Thanks for your work. The actual monetary reward part for this issue is managed by the [Internet Bug Bounty](https://hackerone.com/ibb) so the curl project itself therefor sets the reward amount to **zero USD**. If you haven't already, please submit your reward request to them and refer back to this issue.
My thanks to you as well! I have now submitted a request to the IBB.
